title: E93-1066

sentences.text: This poster paper describes a full scale two-level morphological description -LRB- Karttunen , 1983 ; Koskenniemi , 1983 -RRB- of Turkish word structures .
The description has been implemented using the PC-KIMMO environment -LRB- Antworth , 1990 -RRB- and is based on a root word lexicon of about 23,000 roots words .
Almost all the special cases of and exceptions to phonological and morphological rules have been implemented .
Turkish is an agglutinative language with word structures formed by productive affixations of derivational and inflectional suffixes to root words .
Turkish has finite-state but nevertheless rather complex morphotactics .
Morphemes added to a root word or a stem can convert the word from a nominal to a verbal structure or vice-versa , or can create adverbial constructs .
The surface realizations of morphological constructions are constrained and modified by a number of phonetic rules such as vowel harmony .

Entity-turkish_word_structure.label: Turkish word structures
Entity-turkish_word_structure.description: Turkish word structures refer to the morphological configurations in the Turkish language, characterized by the agglutinative formation of words through the addition of derivational and inflectional suffixes to root words, which are described in detail in the context of a two-level morphological description.

Entity-this_poster_paper.label: This poster paper
Entity-this_poster_paper.description: This poster paper presents a comprehensive two-level morphological analysis of Turkish word structures, utilizing the PC-KIMMO environment and a lexicon of approximately 23,000 root words.

Entity-word_structure.label: word structures
Entity-word_structure.description: The term 'word structures' refers to the morphological configurations in the Turkish language, which are formed through the application of derivational and inflectional suffixes to root words, reflecting the agglutinative nature of Turkish morphology.

Entity-morphological_construction.label: morphological constructions
Entity-morphological_construction.description: Morphological constructions refer to the surface realizations of word structures in Turkish that are formed through the application of phonological and morphological rules, particularly involving the affixation of derivational and inflectional morphemes to root words.

Entity-root_word_lexicon.label: root word lexicon
Entity-root_word_lexicon.description: The 'root word lexicon' refers to a comprehensive collection of approximately 23,000 root words used as the foundational element for morphological analysis in the Turkish language, facilitating the application of phonological and morphological rules within the PC-KIMMO environment.

Entity-karttunen__1983.label: Karttunen, 1983
Entity-karttunen__1983.description: Karttunen, 1983 refers to a foundational work by Lauri Karttunen that presents a two-level morphological description framework, which is utilized in the analysis of Turkish word structures in the context of computational linguistics.

Entity-verbal_structure.label: verbal structure
Entity-verbal_structure.description: The term 'verbal structure' refers to a specific grammatical configuration in Turkish that is formed by the addition of morphemes to a root word or stem, enabling the transformation of a nominal form into a verbal form, thereby indicating the action or state associated with the subject.

Entity-23000_root_word.label: 23,000 roots words
Entity-23000_root_word.description: The mention '23,000 roots words' refers to a comprehensive lexicon of root words used in the morphological analysis of Turkish, which serves as the foundational data set for implementing a two-level morphological description of the language.

Entity-full_scale_two-level_morphologica.label: full scale two-level morphological description
Entity-full_scale_two-level_morphologica.description: A full scale two-level morphological description is a comprehensive framework for analyzing the morphological structure of Turkish words, utilizing a root word lexicon and accounting for complex morphotactic and phonological rules.

Entity-pc-kimmo_environment.label: PC-KIMMO environment
Entity-pc-kimmo_environment.description: The PC-KIMMO environment is a software tool used for implementing morphological descriptions, particularly for agglutinative languages like Turkish, based on a comprehensive root word lexicon.

Entity-koskenniemi__1983.label: Koskenniemi, 1983
Entity-koskenniemi__1983.description: Koskenniemi, 1983 refers to a foundational work by linguist Lauri Koskenniemi that presents a two-level morphological description framework, which is utilized in the analysis of Turkish word structures.

Entity-surface_realization.label: surface realizations
aliases: The surface realizations of morphological constructions
Entity-surface_realization.description: The term 'surface realizations' refers to the actual phonetic forms or outputs of morphological constructions in Turkish, which are influenced and shaped by phonetic rules like vowel harmony.

mentions.local_name: The surface realizations of morphological constructions

Entity-stem.label: stem
Entity-stem.description: In the context of Turkish morphology, 'stem' refers to the base form of a word to which morphemes can be added to create different grammatical structures, such as converting a nominal form to a verbal form.

Entity-derivational_and_inflectional_suf.label: derivational and inflectional suffixes
Entity-derivational_and_inflectional_suf.description: Derivational and inflectional suffixes are morphological elements added to root words in Turkish, enabling the formation of new words and grammatical variations, thereby facilitating the conversion between different word classes and the expression of grammatical relationships.

Entity-antworth__1990.label: Antworth, 1990
Entity-antworth__1990.description: Antworth, 1990 refers to the implementation of the PC-KIMMO environment, which is used for morphological analysis in the study of Turkish word structures.

Entity-karttunen.label: Karttunen
Entity-karttunen.description: Karttunen refers to a researcher and author who contributed to the development of a two-level morphological description of Turkish word structures, as cited in the paper.

Entity-agglutinative_language.label: agglutinative language
Entity-agglutinative_language.description: An agglutinative language is a type of language in which words are formed by stringing together various morphemes, typically through the addition of multiple affixes to a root, allowing for complex word structures that convey grammatical relationships.

Entity-1990.description: The mention '1990' refers to the year in which the PC-KIMMO environment, used for implementing a morphological description of Turkish word structures, was discussed by Antworth.

Entity-special_case.label: special cases
Entity-special_case.description: The term 'special cases' refers to the specific instances and exceptions in the phonological and morphological rules of the Turkish language that have been accounted for in the morphological description presented in the paper.

Entity-nominal.label: nominal
Entity-nominal.description: In the context of Turkish morphology, 'nominal' refers to a grammatical category that encompasses words functioning as nouns or noun-like structures, which can be transformed into verbal forms through morphological processes.

Entity-morphological_rule.label: morphological rules
Entity-morphological_rule.description: Morphological rules are systematic guidelines that govern the structure and formation of words in a language, including the processes of inflection, derivation, and compounding.

Entity-two-level_morphological_descripti.label: two-level morphological description
Entity-two-level_morphological_descripti.description: A two-level morphological description is a theoretical framework used in linguistics to analyze and represent the morphological structure of words by distinguishing between surface forms and underlying forms in a systematic manner.

Entity-morphotactics.label: morphotactics
Entity-morphotactics.description: Morphotactics refers to the rules and patterns governing the arrangement and combination of morphemes within a language to form words.

Entity-morphological_description.label: morphological description
Entity-morphological_description.description: A morphological description is a systematic analysis of the structure and formation of words in a language, focusing on the arrangement and interaction of morphemes.

Entity-affixation.label: affixations
Entity-affixation.description: Affixations are linguistic processes that involve the addition of prefixes, suffixes, or infixes to root words to create new words or modify their meanings and grammatical functions.

Entity-root_word.label: root words
Entity-root_word.description: Root words are the basic, fundamental units of meaning in a language from which other words can be derived through the addition of prefixes, suffixes, or other modifications.

Entity-pc-kimmo.label: PC-KIMMO
Entity-pc-kimmo.description: PC-KIMMO is a computational tool and software environment designed for morphological analysis and generation in linguistics.

Entity-inflectional_suffix.label: inflectional suffixes
Entity-inflectional_suffix.description: Inflectional suffixes are morphemes added to the base form of a word to express grammatical features such as tense, mood, number, or case.

Entity-finite-state.label: finite-state
Entity-finite-state.description: Finite-state refers to a computational model used in various fields such as linguistics and computer science, characterized by a limited number of states and transitions, often employed to analyze and represent patterns in language and morphology.

Entity-turkish.label: Turkish
Entity-turkish.description: Turkish refers to the language spoken primarily in Turkey, as well as the nationality of the people from Turkey.

Entity-morpheme.label: morphemes
Entity-morpheme.description: Morphemes are the smallest units of meaning in a language that can be combined to form words and convey grammatical relationships.

Entity-phonetic_rule.label: phonetic rules
Entity-phonetic_rule.description: Phonetic rules are systematic guidelines in linguistics that govern the pronunciation and articulation of sounds in spoken language.

Entity-koskenniemi.label: Koskenniemi
Entity-koskenniemi.description: Koskenniemi refers to a researcher and author known for contributions to morphological analysis in linguistics.

Entity-vowel_harmony.label: vowel harmony
Entity-vowel_harmony.description: Vowel harmony is a phonological phenomenon in which vowels within a word harmonize to share certain features, such as frontness or backness, affecting the pronunciation and structure of the word.

Entity-adverbial_construct.label: adverbial constructs
Entity-adverbial_construct.description: Adverbial constructs are linguistic elements that modify verbs, adjectives, or other adverbs, typically providing information about the manner, time, place, or degree of the action or state described.

Entity-antworth.label: Antworth
Entity-antworth.description: Antworth refers to a researcher who implemented the PC-KIMMO environment for morphological analysis, as cited in a 1990 publication.

Entity-poster_paper.label: poster paper
Entity-poster_paper.description: A poster paper is a visual presentation of research findings or academic work, typically displayed at conferences or academic events, summarizing key points and results in a concise format.

summary: This poster paper describes a full scale two-level morphological description -LRB- Karttunen , 1983 ; Koskenniemi , 1983 -RRB- of Turkish word structures . The description has been implemented using the PC-KIMMO environment -LRB- Antworth , 1990 -RRB- and is based on a root word lexicon of about 23,000 roots words . Almost all the special cases of and exceptions to phonological and morphological rules have been implemented . Turkish is an agglutinative language with word structures formed by productive affixations of derivational and inflectional suffixes to root words . Turkish has finite-state but nevertheless rather complex morphotactics . Morphemes added to a root word or a stem can convert the word from a nominal to a verbal structure or vice-versa , or can create adverbial constructs . The surface realizations of morphological constructions are constrained and modified by a number of phonetic rules such as vowel harmony .

Predicate-describes.label: describes
Predicate-describes.description: The predicate 'describes' indicates a relationship where the subject provides an explanation, representation, or account of the object. It signifies that the subject conveys information or details about the object, thereby enhancing the understanding of the object through the subject's perspective or content.

Predicate-of.label: of
Predicate-of.description: The predicate 'of' serves to establish a relationship of belonging or association between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject is characterized by, related to, or derived from the object, thereby providing a context or framework within which the subject can be understood. In general, this predicate connects entities by highlighting a specific aspect or feature that the subject possesses in relation to the object.

Predicate-implemented_using.label: implemented using
Predicate-implemented_using.description: The predicate 'implemented using' establishes a relationship between a subject and an object, indicating that the subject is realized or executed through the methods, techniques, or tools represented by the object. It suggests that the object serves as the means or framework through which the subject operates or is constructed.

Predicate-based_on.label: based on
Predicate-based_on.description: The predicate 'based on' indicates a foundational relationship where the subject derives its principles, structure, or functionality from the object. It suggests that the subject is built upon, influenced by, or relies on the object as a primary source or reference point.

Predicate-contains.label: contains
Predicate-contains.description: The predicate 'contains' indicates that the subject includes or holds within it the object, signifying a relationship where the subject encompasses or is made up of the elements represented by the object. This relationship often implies that the object is a subset or a component of the subject, highlighting the presence of specific items, quantities, or characteristics within the broader context of the subject.

Predicate-are_exceptions_to.label: are exceptions to
Predicate-are_exceptions_to.description: The predicate 'are exceptions to' indicates that the subject does not conform to the general principles or norms represented by the object. It highlights a distinction where the subject is recognized as an anomaly or deviation from the established rules or patterns associated with the object.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: The predicate 'has' indicates a relationship of possession or inclusion between the subject and the object. It signifies that the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the object, establishing a connection where the subject is defined or described in part by the presence of the object.

Predicate-attached_to.label: attached to
Predicate-attached_to.description: The predicate 'attached to' indicates a relationship where the subject is physically or conceptually connected to the object, suggesting that the subject is affixed, linked, or associated with the object in a way that modifies, enhances, or complements its meaning or function.

Predicate-include.label: include
Predicate-include.description: The predicate 'include' establishes a relationship where the subject encompasses or contains the object as part of its broader category or set. It indicates that the object is a component or element that is recognized as belonging to the subject, thereby highlighting the relationship of membership or incorporation.

Predicate-added_to.label: added to
Predicate-added_to.description: The predicate 'added to' indicates a relationship where the subject is combined with or incorporated into the object, resulting in a new or modified entity. This connection implies that the subject contributes additional elements, characteristics, or features to the object, enhancing or altering its original form or function.

Predicate-create.label: create
Predicate-create.description: The predicate 'create' signifies the action of bringing something into existence or forming it from existing elements. In the context of the triple, it indicates that the subject (e.g., morphemes) is actively involved in the process of producing or generating the object (e.g., adverbial constructs). This relationship highlights a transformative process where the subject contributes foundational components that result in the formation of the object.

Predicate-can_create.label: can create
Predicate-can_create.description: The predicate 'can create' indicates the ability or potential of the subject to produce or generate the object. It establishes a relationship where the subject possesses the capability to bring forth or construct the object, suggesting a dynamic interaction between the two elements. This predicate implies that the subject has the necessary resources, skills, or conditions to initiate the formation of the object.

Predicate-are_constrained_and_modified_b.label: are constrained and modified by
Predicate-are_constrained_and_modified_b.description: The predicate 'are constrained and modified by' indicates a relationship where the subject is influenced and shaped by the object, suggesting that the characteristics or behaviors of the subject are limited or altered in accordance with the principles, guidelines, or rules represented by the object. This implies a dynamic interaction where the subject cannot exist or function independently of the constraints and modifications imposed by the object.

Predicate-such_as.label: such as
Predicate-such_as.description: The predicate 'such as' is used to introduce examples or specific instances that illustrate or clarify the subject. It connects the subject to the object by indicating that the object is a representative example of the broader category or concept denoted by the subject.

Predicate-are_a_specific_instance_of.label: are a specific instance of
Predicate-are_a_specific_instance_of.description: The predicate 'are a specific instance of' establishes a relationship where the subject is identified as a particular example or case that falls under the broader category represented by the object. It indicates that the subject shares defining characteristics or properties with the object, thereby situating the subject within a specific subset of a larger classification.

Predicate-presents_a_comprehensive_two-l.label: presents a comprehensive two-level morphological analysis of
Predicate-presents_a_comprehensive_two-l.description: The predicate 'presents a comprehensive two-level morphological analysis of' indicates that the subject is providing an in-depth examination or study that is structured in two distinct levels, focusing on the morphological aspects of the object. This implies a detailed exploration of the form and structure of the object, which in this context refers to a specific linguistic element or system.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates a hierarchical relationship where the subject represents a specific instance or category that falls under a more general category represented by the object. This relationship implies that the subject is a subset or a more specific example of the broader concept denoted by the object, thereby establishing a connection between the two in terms of classification or categorization.
